channel.title: Stories from bbc.com - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best bbc.com stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: The Untold Story Of America's Biggest Coronavirus Outbreak
item.description: How did the biggest cluster in the US emerge in a corner of South Dakota? Infections spread like wildfire through a pork factory and questions remain about what the company did to protect staff.

item.title: Wuhan Raises Coronavirus Death Toll By 50%
item.description: The revision of Wuhan's toll comes amid growing skepticism over the transparency of China's response.

item.title: The Green Sludge That Could Transform Our Diets
item.description: Microalgae is rich in protein, amino acids, fatty acids and vitamins. Should we all be eating it?

item.title: The Many Languages Missing From The Internet
item.description: English and a handful of other languages dominate the internet, but this is leaving indigenous cultures without a voice online. Now they are fighting back.

item.title: Keirin School: Inside The Strict And Secret World Of Bicycle Racing In Japan
item.description: Keirin racing in Japan is a big business that is rich in traditions too. Its intriguing world says a lot about our Olympics hosts.

item.title: The Woman Who Discovered The First Coronavirus
item.description: The woman who discovered the first human coronavirus was the daughter of a Scottish bus driver, who left school at 16.

item.title: Newly-Enhanced Images Of Life On Apollo 13
item.description: Unsurprisingly, given they were locked in a fight for survival, relatively few onboard images were taken. But imaging specialist Andy Saunders created sharp stills from low-quality 16mm film shot by the crew.

item.title: Why COVID-19 Is Different For Men And Women
item.description: COVID-19 has profoundly different outcomes for men and women - and not just in terms of their health. For a virus that infects people indiscriminately, why does gender have such an effect?
item.kicker: TWICE AS MANY MEN ARE DYING

item.title: New York Using Mass Graves Amid Coronavirus Outbreak
item.description: Drone footage shows coffins stacked in a pit in the city, as the state logs more cases than any country.

item.title: Why Has Turkmenistan Reported No Cases Of Coronavirus?
item.description: While many countries have imposed major restrictions, life continues as normal in Turkmenistan.

item.title: Which Foods Will Survive The Apocalypse?
item.description: Should the human population disappear tomorrow, what might future archaeologists find of the food we eat? And, most importantly, would any of it still be edible?

item.title: Three Out Of Four Americans Under Some Form Of Lockdown Because Of Coronavirus
item.description: About three out of four Americans are now, or about to be, under some form of lockdown, as more states tighten measures to fight the coronavirus.

item.title: Bahariya And Farafra: Egypt's Bizarre, Desert Landscape
item.description: The Bahariya and Farafra depressions have some of the rarest landscapes in Egypt, making one forget, for a moment, that the Pyramids are the country's biggest attraction.

item.title: 'Virus-Fighting' Scientist Gets Magnets Stuck In Nose
item.description: Dr. Daniel Reardon came up with a plan to create a necklace which would react if your hands were near your face. Unfortunately, the device did not work quite as planned.

item.title: Bob Weighton Turns 112: The Times And Life Of The World's Oldest Man
item.description: Bob Weighton, from Hampshire, turns 112 today. What has the world's oldest man lived through?

item.title: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson Tests Positive For Coronavirus
item.description: Johnson has mild symptoms and will self-isolate in Downing Street.

item.title: Prince Charles Tests Positive For Coronavirus But 'Remains In Good Health'
item.description: The Prince of Wales, 71, is displaying mild symptoms "but otherwise remains in good health", a spokesman said, adding that the Duchess of Cornwall, 72, has been tested but does not have the virus.

item.title: Trump Wants US Open For Business Amid Pandemic
item.description: As a growing number of states issue "shelter in place" orders, businesses shutter and Americans everywhere are told to limit outings and practice social distancing, Donald Trump may be having second thoughts.

item.title: 'You Must Stay At Home': Entire UK Goes Under Coronavirus Lockdown
item.description: People in Britain will be allowed to leave their homes for only "very limited purposes" — shopping for basic necessities; for one form of exercise a day; for any medical need; and to travel to and from work when "absolutely necessary."

item.title: How Chronic Renters Are Reshaping The Homeware Industry
item.description: Home ownership is a distant dream for many millennials — but they still want stylish, personalized rental homes. Their ambitions are changing the homeware industry.

item.title: How Long Does The Coronavirus Last On Surfaces?
item.description: We can pick up the COVID-19 by touching surfaces contaminated with the new coronavirus, but it is only just becoming clear how long the virus can survive outside the human body.

item.title: Italy Coronavirus Deaths Rise By Record 475 In A Day
item.description: Italy has been on lockdown for almost two weeks as authorities try to halt the progress of the virus. People have been asked to stay indoors — but the number of deaths has continued to spiral.

item.title: How Long Does The Coronavirus Last On Surfaces?
item.description: We can pick up the Covid-19 by touching surfaces contaminated with the new coronavirus, but it is only just becoming clear how long the virus can survive outside the human body.

item.title: The French Republic No One Knows
item.description: In the Saugeais valley, there's a tiny micronation with its own flag. It's not recognised by the French state, but that hasn't stopped locals from electing their own president.

item.title: Strikes Kill 25 Iran-Backed Fighters In Iraq Base Attack
item.description: A British soldier and two Americans serving in Iraq were killed by the rockets fired.

item.title: Canada Has A Mysterious Lake Monster, Too
item.description: For generations, a mythical beast has been said to lurk in the depths of Okanagan Lake. But now a new view on British Columbia's most revered serpent is taking hold.

item.title: Japan's Ancient Way To Save The Planet
item.description: The concept of mottainai encompasses the idea of respecting resources and not wasting them, along with an inherent recognition of their value.

item.title: Coronavirus: Northern Italy Quarantines 16 Million People
item.description: A quarter of the population is in lockdown as Italy takes drastic action to control Covid-19.

item.title: Why Japan Is Obsessed With Paper
item.description: For a country often depicted as the pinnacle of high-tech living Japan has a surprising and enduring obsession with paper. That might finally be changing.

item.title: The Shady Past Of The Color Pink
item.description: A hue now associated with innocence once had a murkier meaning: Kelly Grovier looks at the ways in which pink has represented violence and seduction.

item.title: How The Humble Potato Changed The World
item.description: A staple food for cultures across the globe, the tuber has emerged as a nutritional giant and the friend of peasants, rulers and sages.

item.title: The Man Who Refused To Freeze To Death
item.description: Lost, wet and alone in a freezing, snow-covered landscape, an Icelandic fisherman's story of survival against the odds reveals the human body's remarkable ability to adapt to the cold.

item.title: China Pollution Clears Amid Coronavirus Slowdown
item.description: Satellite images have shown a dramatic decline in pollution levels over China, which is "at least partly" due to an economic slowdown prompted by the coronavirus, NASA says.

item.title: The Boss Who Put Everyone On $70K — Five Years Later
item.description: Gravity Payments CEO Dan Price introduced a $70,000 minimum salary for all his staff — by cutting his own wages. Five years on, he has no regrets.

item.title: Spain's Mysterious Underwater 'Stonehenge'
item.description: Thought to be more than 4,000 years old, the Dolmen of Guadalperal was "invisible" for almost 60 years until it unexpectedly reappeared.

item.title: Secret Doorway Discovered In UK Parliament Leads To Historical Treasure Trove
item.description: A forgotten passageway used by prime ministers and political luminaries – and closed up by Victorian labourers – has been uncovered in Parliament.

item.title: What Happens When The Internet Vanishes?
item.description: During a troublesome protest or tricky election, some countries just cut the online cord.

item.title: How To Win Monopoly In The Shortest Possible Time
item.description: One of the best-selling board games of all time makes several cardinal sins of good design, which means it has attracted a great deal of ire over the years.

item.title: Who Is 'Patient Zero' In The Coronavirus Outbreak?
item.description: As the cases of coronavirus increase in China and around the world, the hunt is on to identify "patient zero." But can singling out one person in an outbreak do more harm than good?
item.kicker: GETTING TO THE BOTTOM OF IT

item.title: Is Gothenburg Europe's Greenest City?
item.description: For three years in a row, Sweden's second-largest city has been declared the world's most sustainable destination.

item.title: Tyson Fury Beats Deontay Wilder In World Title Fight In Las Vegas
item.description: Tyson Fury wins the WBC world heavyweight title after producing a sensational performance against Deontay Wilder.

item.title: A Single Tree The Size Of A Forest
item.description: Flourishing within one of India's driest regions, the banyan tree Thimmamma Marrimanu has become an enduring symbol of eternal life.

item.title: The Simple Math Error That Can Lead To Bankruptcy
item.description: The "gambler's fallacy" — which can affect everyone from athletes to loan officers — creates deceptive biases that lead you to anticipate patterns that don't really exist.

item.title: The Japanese Village That Eats Wasps
item.description: For generations, families across Japan have hunted, raised and eaten wasps. But will this age-old delicacy soon vanish?

item.title: Can Humans Really Make The World Better?
item.description: Humanity is turning to technology to resurrect lost species and create artificial life, but is it worth it if we can't protect the natural world we have around us?
item.kicker: WELL, WE BETTER. TIME'S RUNNING OUT

item.title: Why So Many Of The World's Oldest Companies Are In Japan
item.description: The country has 33,000 businesses at least a century old. How have so many survived - and what does it mean for Japan's future?

item.title: The Clever Glass Box That Reshaped The World
item.description: Wardian cases safely took plants across the world, revolutionising agriculture, politics and trade.

item.title: Two Citizen Journalists Reported On Coronavirus From Wuhan. Now They've Disappeared
item.description: They posted videos online, shared pictures and dramatic stories from inside the quarantined city that has been virtually cut off from the rest of the country. Now, Fang Bin and Chen Qiushi are nowhere to be found.

item.title: The Downsides To A Plant-Based Diet
item.description: The vegan diet is widely regarded to be better for the planet than those that include animal products, but not all plant-based foodstuffs have a small environmental footprint.

item.title: The Welsh Island Dedicated To Love
item.description: Pilgrims have sought love on Llanddwyn Island for millennia. Now, the story of Saint Dwynwen, Wales' patron saint of lovers, is gaining a new following.
